newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan eases some China investments, bans others.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan eases some China investments, bans others.

text.p: Taiwan said on Wednesday it would allow local firms to engage in a wider range of investments in arch rival China, but slapped an outright ban on real estate and large power plant projects.
"The Investment Commission and relevant departments decided late on Tuesday to remove investment constraints on 411 mainland categories," a commission spokesman said.
Approval by the economics ministry and cabinet were likely, officials said.

The liberalisation gives a green light to travel agencies, hotels, recreation facilities, warehouses, merchandise agents, rental businesses, saunas, printing machines, sewing machines and car and motorcycle parts, the commission spokesman said.
The 411 categories had been permitted, but only by firms whose investment proposals had obtained explicit commission approval, the official said.
There remain 2,477 items in this discretionary category.

The spokesman said property and power plant projects had been moved from the discretionary category and placed on a "ban list" -- 299 items where China investments by Taiwan interests remain forbidden.

The spokesman noted, however, that the power plant ban would apply only to large projects. Small hydropower plants and steam and electricity co-generation facilities with capacity of up to 20 megawatts would be permitted, he said.
The decision nonetheless would put an explicit end to Formosa Plastics Group's plan to invest US$3 billion in a 3,600-megawatt mainland power station.
A dejected Formosa spokesman told Reuters: "We have no more power plant (project) on the mainland now."

He said Formosa group could only "patiently wait" for a shift in policy by the Nationalist government, which has grown wary of allowing Taiwan to become overdependent on the economy of its arch rival.
Taiwan, which has banned direct links with China since a civil war split them in 1949, has allowed a range of "indirect" investments under a political thaw dating to the late 1980s.
Some 4,350 investment types are permitted, though capital must be routed through Hong Kong or a third country.

In its drive to avoid becoming economically vulnerable in China, Taipei said in late May it was restricting investment in mainland infrastructure -- specifically water works, railways, harbours, airports, roads and power plants.
